properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall is forecast for Rogers Pass on Tuesday. A strong frontal system will cross the province on Tuesday. Freezing levels will fall in advance of the system then a moisture laden airmass will sweep through on Tuesday. 15 cm of snow is expected Tuesday with a possible additional 10 to 15 cm Tuesday night. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T14:03:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T22:04:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0689886144.2020
Area: Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues tonight. General amounts of 20 to 30 mm are expected before the rain tapers off overnight. However, it is possible that local amounts may approach 50 mm, especially in thunderstorms. Localized flooding is possible. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District office. Visit Ontario.ca/floods for the latest details. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre will approach the South Coast tonight and move across Vancouver Island on Tuesday morning. Winds will rise to southeast 70 gusting to 100 km/h over Western Vancouver Island late this evening, and to southeast 60 gusting to 90 km/h overnight for communities near northern Georgia Strait. Winds will snap to westerly or southwesterly 50 to 70 gusting up to 90 km/h or higher Tuesday morning. Winds will ease by Tuesday evening as the low moves into the interior. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T14:46:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T22:47:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1601131974.2020

properties.Title: Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Conditions are favourable for the development of squalls with wind gusts up to 35 knots and poor to very poor visibility in snow squalls. Snow squalls over Great Slave Lake are likely to develop beginning on Tuesday afternoon and persisting through the overnight hours into Wednesday morning. ### Poor to very poor visibility may contribute to voyage delays and make marine navigation hazardous. Proceed with caution as visibility may suddenly be reduced to near zero. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. For more information monitor Canadian Coast Guard radio or Weatheradio stations.
Expires: 2020-10-13T14:43:12-00:00

Area: Great Slave Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Widespread, strong and gusty winds on Tuesday... A new low pressure system will cross Vancouver Island Tuesday morning and continue into the interior late in the day. Areas of Metro Vancouver near the Strait of Georgia, Victoria, and the Gulf Islands will see winds rising to southeast 30 to 50 km/h gusting to 70 km/h overnight. The second windy wallop comes on Tuesday as winds abruptly transition from southeasterly to strong and gusty westerlies. Winds will rise to 50 to 70 km/h Tuesday morning for Vancouver Island and spread to the mainland Tuesday afternoon. Widespread gusts of 80 km/h or higher are possible. Some key notes... 1) strong westerly winds will be widespread. 2) The exact location of the strongest winds depends on the track and depth of the low. Please monitor local forecasts for updates. Impacts such as broken tree limbs and power outages are possible. Winds are expected to ease Tuesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T14:49:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T22:50:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3252506553.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy rain is expected Tuesday night into Wednesday. Total rainfall: 20 to 40 mm. Locally higher amounts possible. Maximum wind gusts: 50 to 70 km/h along the Fundy coast. Locations: New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday evening through Wednesday. Remarks: Rain will begin Tuesday evening over western regions and spread eastward into the overnight hours, becoming heavy at times. The rain is expected taper to showers Wednesday morning and clear out in the afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Summary:

Conditions will be favourable for frost overnight tonight, especially in low lying areas. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong low pressure system is expected to impact the eastern Kitikmeot starting this evening and will continue through to Thursday October 15, 2020. The exact track of the system is still uncertain. Expected conditions over the region include: Strong easterly winds gusting to 70 km/h, heavy snowfall, blowing snow, and a risk of freezing rain or ice pellets. Total snowfall amounts associated with this system remain uncertain at this point in time, but could range between 10-15 cm by Thursday afternoon. As the system approaches and confidence regarding the conditions and impacts increases, the Winter Storm Watches may be upgraded to Winter Storm Warnings. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T11:29:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T19:30:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0535183387.2020
Area: Taloyoak

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rain and wind is expected. Total rainfall: possibly more than 50 mm. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly near 100 km/h in the Wreckhouse area. Locations: southwestern Newfoundland. Time span: Wednesday morning to Thursday morning. Remarks: Winds will strengthen in the Wreckhouse area Tuesday night and reach their peak during the day on Wednesday. The winds will diminish as they shift to the southwest Wednesday night. Rain will develop on Wednesday and may become heavy, at times, Wednesday night. The rain is expected to taper off by Thursday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Another round of snow is expected tonight for BC highway passes. A frontal system will move through southern BC tonight. This system will usher in colder air which will cause snow levels to fall to near 1000 m overnight. Snow is expected to begin overnight, before changing over to rain Tuesday as snow levels rise. For Allison Pass (Hope to Princeton): 10 cm is expected overnight and Tuesday morning. For Coquihalla Summit (Hope to Merritt): 5 to 10 cm is possible tonight. For Surrey Lake Summit on the Coquihalla (Merritt to Kamloops): 5 cm is possible late tonight and early Tuesday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T10:21:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T18:22:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2372761050.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Conditions are favourable for the development of snow squalls over Great Slave Lake starting on Tuesday afternoon and persisting through the overnight hours into Wednesday morning. 15 to 20 cm of snow may fall over localized areas. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
